seg.output:
Peace from God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ to you. Amen.
Seeing as all my hopes are placed in you, a man so wise and kind, I have taken the liberty to pour out my sorrows to you, doubting not that you would forgive me should I unwittingly have sinned. For God is pleased to overlook the fault of those who approach Him in faith.
Behold, my dearest teacher, how I am held back by cunning hindrances. Before I had planned this journey, the magistrate of Alsteten had promised me such diligence that on my return I would have nothing to do but receive my wages and depart with my affairs settled. But it happened otherwise. New delays are put in my way and meanwhile they threaten me with things that are not. Though the Voglers are envious, it is I who suffer the harm. So my return will be slower than I wish and than is expedient. But I beseech you through Christ, most holy man, to keep the minds of my patrons in their duty and, if need be, to mollify them, especially so that you may, through your prudence, be of service to me. I write this not as thinking that my presence would be of any value, but rather lest I be estranged from your good-will.

seg.output:
Behold, my dearest teacher, how I am detained by cunning delays. Before I undertook this journey, the magistrates of Alsted promised their diligence in such a way that upon my return I would have nothing to do but receive my pay and set off with my affairs in order. But the opposite happened. They impose new delays on me. Meanwhile, they utter things that are not true. Although Vogler is the object of envy, I suffer the damage. Therefore, my return will be slower than I would like or expedite. But I beseech you, most pious man, through Christ to keep the minds of the patrons in their duty and, if necessary, to appease them, especially that you may also advise them well through your prudence. I do not write this as though I thought my presence would be of any avail, but that I might not be backed away from your kindness. If you perceived the wiles of these men, which I myself am deploring, you would certainly have pity on me and mine, and would be angry at the tricks of these men. Nor do I consider the loss to be greatest on my part, inasmuch as I am taking up the due wages in full, but that I must be absent from your sermons and lectures.

I entrust, recommend and give myself to you, most excellent man.
Farewell, happily. Greet your father and wife.
Given at Alsted, January 16, 1532.
Your Carolstadius.
My neighbor Heinrich, born and educated at Zurich, heartily wishes you well. His probity and learning pleases me greatly. He asked me to commend him to you, though he could have done it himself more politely and better, and I need a commendator.
